title: About
text:
The jellydata project was developed at Bigelow Laboratory’s Tandy Center for Ocean Forecasting to aid in the development of modeling studies requiring either observation/abundance point data or to modeled rasterized layers for subsequent use in modeling studies. Use the github issues tracker to post questions or report issues.

credit Colby, Bigelow
blurb about Nick, Ben, Logan




 Back to top

title: White Cross Jellyfish
text:
The Whitecross jelly (Staurostoma mertensii) is a less commonly observed species, named for the distinct white cross-shaped markings on its bell. It inhabits cold, northern waters and has been documented in regions such as coastal Norway.


This species remains relatively mysterious compared to other jellyfish, and sightings are often of scientific interest. Its delicate body and unique markings make it visually striking when encountered by divers or captured in photographs.


Learn more: Wikimedia Commons Photo



1 Today’s Forecast











2 Observation Distributions


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = obs, color = "red", size = 1.5) +
  coord_sf(
    xlim = c(coast_bbox["xmin"], coast_bbox["xmax"]),
    ylim = c(coast_bbox["ymin"], coast_bbox["ymax"]),
    expand = FALSE
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "White Cross Jelly Observations") +
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())









Code
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = obs, color = "red", size = 1.5, alpha = 0.7) +
  coord_sf(
    xlim = c(coast_bbox["xmin"], coast_bbox["xmax"]),
    ylim = c(coast_bbox["ymin"], coast_bbox["ymax"]),
    expand = FALSE
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ year) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "White Cross Jelly Observations by Year") +
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())









Code
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = obs, color = "red", size = 1.5, alpha = 0.7) +
  coord_sf(
    xlim = c(coast_bbox["xmin"], coast_bbox["xmax"]),
    ylim = c(coast_bbox["ymin"], coast_bbox["ymax"]),
    expand = FALSE
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ month) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "White Cross Jelly Observations by Month") +
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())











3 Proportion of Observations Histograms


Code
ggplot(obs, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_bar(aes(y = after_stat(prop), group = 1), fill = "steelblue") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Proportion of White Cross Jelly Observations per Year",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Proportion"
  )









Code
ggplot(obs, aes(x = month)) +
  geom_bar(aes(y = after_stat(prop), group = 1), fill = "steelblue") +
  scale_x_discrete(drop = FALSE) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Proportion of White Cross Jelly Observations per Month",
    x = "Month",
    y = "Proportion"
  )

title: Lion’s Mane Jellyfish
text:
The lion’s mane jellyfish (Cyanea capillata) is one of the largest known species of jellyfish, named for its long, trailing tentacles that resemble a lion’s mane. It can have a bell diameter of over 2 meters (6.5 feet) and tentacles extending more than 30 meters (100 feet), though most are much smaller.


These jellyfish are typically found in the cold, northern waters of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, especially in the Gulf of Maine, Arctic, and North Sea. They drift with ocean currents and feed on small fish, plankton, and other jellyfish, capturing prey with stinging cells in their tentacles.


While their sting is painful, it is usually not dangerous to humans. Encounters are most common during the summer months, when they come closer to shore.


Learn more: Wikipedia – Lion’s Mane Jellyfish NOAA Ocean Service Aquarium of the Pacific



1 Today’s Forecast











2 Observation Distributions

title: gom-jellies-dev
text:
For the gom-jellies project, observations come from community scientist reports. The following species have been selected for analysis:

Cyanea capillata (Lion’s Mane)
Aurelia aurita (Moon)
Staurostoma mertensii (White Cross)
Ctenophores (Comb)

title: Moon Jellyfish
text:
The moon jelly (Aurelia aurita) is a widely distributed and easily recognizable jellyfish, known for its translucent, saucer-shaped bell and four horseshoe-shaped gonads visible through the top. It typically grows to about 25–40 cm (10–16 inches) in diameter.


Moon jellies are found in coastal waters around the world and prefer calm bays and harbors. They feed mainly on small plankton and fish eggs, using their fringe of short tentacles and mucus-covered bell to trap food.


While their sting is harmless to humans, they are often studied in aquariums and marine biology for their simple body structure and gentle movement.


Learn more: Wikipedia – Moon Jelly Aquarium of the Pacific



1 Today’s Forecast











2 Observation Distributions


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = obs, color = "red", size = 1.5) +

    ylim = c(coast_bbox["ymin"], coast_bbox["ymax"]),
    expand = FALSE
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Moon Jelly Observations") +
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())

  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +

  coord_sf(
    xlim = c(coast_bbox["xmin"], coast_bbox["xmax"]),
    ylim = c(coast_bbox["ymin"], coast_bbox["ymax"]),
    expand = FALSE
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ year) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Moon Jelly Observations by Year") +
  theme(axis.title = element_blank())









Code

  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = obs, color = "red", size = 1.5, alpha = 0.7) +

title: Comb Jellyfish
text:
Comb jellies, or ctenophores, are gelatinous marine animals known for their shimmering rows of cilia—called “combs”—that they use for swimming. Although similar in appearance to jellyfish, comb jellies belong to a separate phylum and lack stinging cells.


They come in various shapes and sizes, often with beautiful iridescent colors that reflect light as they move. Many species are bioluminescent, lighting up with blue or green flashes in the dark.


Comb jellies are important predators of zooplankton and are found in oceans worldwide, from surface waters to the deep sea.


Learn more: Wikipedia – Comb Jelly Wikimedia Commons Photo



1 Today’s Forecast











2 Observation Distributions


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = coast, color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = obs, color = "red", size = 1.5) +
